p: Curcuma longa L. (Zingiberaceae) is known to contain two main classes of secondary metabolites, phenolic curcuminoids, and essential oils, including the major components α-turmerone and β-turmerone. Despite the essential oil from Curcuma longa L. administered via intraperitoneal injection demonstrating a strong antiarthritic effect in female rats with SCW-induced arthritis, significant morbidity and mortality have been observed, which do not support the use of this EO against arthritis [ 97]. On the contrary, a good antiarthritic effect has been demonstrated in experimental rheumatoid arthritis for curcuminoid-containing turmeric extracts [ 98], and good antiarthritic potential has been observed for curcumin, the principal curcuminoid of turmeric. Nonose and coworkers demonstrated that this compound was able to reduce the inflammatory response in zymosan-induced arthritis [ 99].
